description: Erection of Piggyback roof extension to facilitate loft conversion with 8no rooflights and 1no new sash window to rear gable
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission. Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The materials and finishes of the external walls and roof the development hereby approved shall match in colour and texture to those of the existing building, or such other materials as shall have been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and shall thereafter be retained as such. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the roof light serving the bathroom as shown on the approved drawings shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
RBK Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied Condition 42 (Car Park Management Plan) can now be approved.

Application SiteThe site comprises a two storey terraced dwelling.ProposalThe application seeks the conversion of the property used as 2no. self-contained flats into a single family dwellinghouseNo external changes are proposed, other than general improvement work and landscaping. Consultation14 properties were notified of the proposal. Two representations were received in support of the proposal to be converted to a single family dwelling. In particular that amenities would improve. RBK Environmental Health Team - no objection subject to hours of work being restricted as recommended (secured by condition)AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The planning history;- The principle of the development;- The standard of the proposed accommodation;- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers;- The impact of the development on highway safety;- Cycle parking; and,- Car parking.Planning HistoryPlanning permission was previously refused under application reference 21/01078/CPU for the conversion of property used as 2no. self-contained flats into a single family dwellinghouse. The reasons for refusing that application were:The proposed conversion of two residential units into one residential dwelling is considered to amount to development constituting a material change of use under Section 55(1) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.Under the provisions of section 57 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, planning permission is required for the use, however, planning permission has not been granted for the development by way of a development order or by the Local Planning Authority.Principle of DevelopmentPolicy H1 of the London Plan 2021 sets a target for the Borough of 9,640 net housing completions within the next ten years. Planning decisions should optimise the potential for housing delivery on all suitable and available brownfield sites to ensure that this target is met.Policy H8 of the London Plan 2021 states that the loss of existing housing should be replaced by new housing at existing or higher densities with at least the equivalent level of overall floorspace. Policy DM14 of the Core Strategy states the Council will resist the loss of existing accommodation (of all types) and, in particular, dwellings which are suitable for family accommodation. The site is in an established residential area. It is not subject to any designations or environmental constraints that might fundamentally conflict with conversion of the property into a single dwelling. It is also noted that the original use of the property was as a single dwelling and converted into two x 1 bed flats some years ago (circa 1986). Although the proposal would not provide new housing of the same or higher density, it would retain the use of property for housing and also provide a family dwelling meeting an identified need, in accordance with DM14 of the Core Strategy.It is also noted that many of the properties along Douglas Road are in use as single dwelling houses and whilst difficult to determine the extent to which any of these may have been subdivided into flats, externally they mostly have the appearance of family-sized homes. Having regard to the above, officers consider that there is no in principle reason to resist the development.Standard of AccommodationPolicy D6 of the London Plan 2021 sets out the standards for new housing within London, in terms of overall gross internal area ("GIA"), built-in storage space, bedroom sizes and ceiling heights. Housing development should be of high quality design and provide adequately-sized rooms, with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures. Policy DM13 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 states that the Council will expect proposals for new residential development to demonstrate that the scheme has been designed to provide adequate internal space appropriate to the intended number of occupants.The applicant has demonstrated that the proposed internal areas will be vastly improved by conversion of the property with adequate room sizes and layout. The 3 bed dwelling would meet the minimum internal space standards set out in Table 3.1 of the London Plan with a total of 124.69m2 of floor space (2021). Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires developments to provide adequate private and/or communal amenity space. Policy Guidance 13 of the Council's Residential Design SPD states that although levels of private amenity space may vary considerably in different character areas, each new dwelling should have a minimum of 50sqm of private garden (plus an extra 5 sqm for each bedroom after the third), where the prevailing character allows.The proposed dwelling would both benefit from a rear garden in excess of the requirements of Policy Guidance 13.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. All works associated with the proposed change of use are internal. Officers therefore consider the development would preserve the character and appearance of the surrounding area. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.As noted above all proposed works associated with the proposed change of use are internal and given the conversion from two flats to a single dwelling, which would minimise the intensity of use, officers are satisfied that the proposal would not result in any unacceptable adverse impacts on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers in terms of overbearing appearance, loss of light, loss of privacy, or any other environmental harms.Highway Safety and Car ParkingPolicy T4 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should reflect and be integrated with current and planned transport access, capacity and connectivity. Where appropriate, mitigation, either through direct provision of public transport, walking and cycling facilities and highways improvements or through financial contributions, will be required to address adverse transport impacts that are identified. Development proposals should not increase road danger.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected.Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals. Where provided, each motorcycle parking space should count towards the maximum for car parking spaces at all use classes.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.The property has a PTAL rating of 2. The maximum residential parking standard set out in the London Plan for a one bed dwelling is 0.75 spaces per flat. For a three bedroomed property the maximum standard is one space per dwelling. Whilst there is no provision of off street parking, the proposal will reduce the number of dwellings on site and the intensity of use of the site. Officers are therefore satisfied that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on highway safety and likely reduction in the demand for on street parking.Cycle ParkingPolicy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3, ensuring that a minimum of two short-stay and two long-stay cycle parking spaces are provided.Policy DM8 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require new development to provide facilities on-site for cyclists as appropriate, including showers, lockers and secure, convenient cycle parking, in accordance with the minimum standards set out in the London Plan.No provision is shown for cycle parking however this will be secured by condition and officers note there is sufficient space on site to ensure adequate cycle parking can be provided.  ConclusionThe scheme under consideration involves the provision of housing and the Council cannot demonstrate a five year supply of deliverable housing sites. Therefore, the "tilted balance" as set out in paragraph 11 of the NPPF is engaged.The proposed development would provide one less dwelling on the site, at a time when the supply of land for housing within the Borough is constrained. Notwithstanding, the proposal would retain residential use of the property, would provide family accommodation that is an identified need in the Borough, of a higher quality than currently exists.    Further, the impact of the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area, on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers, and on highway safety would be acceptable. The standard of the proposed outdoor space and the level of proposed cycle parking would also be acceptable. These are neutral matters.Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be contrary to aspects of the development plan. However, Paragraph 11 of the NPPF is a material consideration and officers consider that the adverse impacts of granting permission would not significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against the policies in the NPPF as a whole. Accordingly, Paragraph 11 warrants a decision other than in accordance with the development plan and officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that the Planning Condition 30 of planning permission 19/01228/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

Please provide a copy of proposed block plan scaled 1:500, providing a scale bar showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.The submitted proposed site plan does not show the proposed development in hatched or shaded.

Please provide existing floor plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works.The scale bar in the submitted existing floor plans does not measure to the stated scale.
